comment.author: 25797459@N06
comment._content:
What would this have been flown from out of interest?
I know this is a maritime museum page and it looks far too large for a ship.
Ive added a few tags hope you dont mind feel free to delete them.

comment.author: 11334970@N05
comment._content:
Hi zaphad,

Thank you for your question. 

The size of this flag is amazing, and although it looks too big to be flown from the mast of a ship it actually is not. The flag was flown from the main mast of Earl Howe's ship, the 'Queen Charlotte', in a naval battle against the French in June 1794.

comment.author: 25797459@N06
comment._content:
Amazing! Thank you for the reply.
Is this the world record largest union jack or navy flag that actually saw use? 
do you know?
It must be near it

comment.author: 11334970@N05
comment._content:
Hi zaphad,

The flag here at the Museum is not the largest flag that the navy used. 

In 1687 Samuel Pepys drew a table which records - in modern terms - the length of the jack of a first rate as 6.4 metres long (7 yards). Our flag is 100 years later and 5.588 metres long.
